page.title: 18PLANT LIFE ON WHALSAY
page.content: As Whalsay is at times subject to severe weather with salt from the sea in the air right across the island all plants have to be able to resist this. There are now no native trees on the island,although evidence from peat deposits shows that there used to be varieties of willow and alder. As much of the island is wet,acid peat based soil mosses,grasses and plants such as Bog Cotton,Common Orchids and Butterwort thrive.In sheltered places some ferns grow.On drier areas vetches,thrift and sheeps bit scabious are found.Over drier areas of the hill there are amounts of heather.
